Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation2: An acquaintance makes a negative comment about a colleague's recent work performance.
Story:
I was sitting in the break room, my phone buzzing with frantic messages from my younger brother. He’d just found out he didn’t get into his dream university, and his words were raw with disappointment. As his sibling, I knew he needed me—someone to listen, to reassure him that he was more than a rejection letter. I wanted to call him right away, to be the shoulder he could lean on.

But just then, an acquaintance from work slid into the seat beside me, sighing loudly. “Did you see Mark’s latest project? Honestly, I don’t know how he still has a job here.” She looked at me, expecting agreement or at least a reaction. I remembered the unspoken rule among acquaintances: don’t gossip, don’t fuel negativity. I felt trapped, torn between the urge to defend Mark and the pressure to fit in, all while my brother’s pain echoed in my mind. My heart pounded as I tried to balance the weight of being a good sibling and a respectful acquaintance, feeling the demands of both roles pulling me in opposite directions.
